Fig. 1 (a, b) Ethane and NO conversions, (c) Stability test and 4 % H2O + 40 ppm SO2 resistance on Ce-γ-MnO2, (d) Arrhenius plots of ethane oxidation, (e) Specific reaction rate normalized by BET surface area for ethane oxidation at 300 °C on Ce-X-MnO2, and (f) Ethane and NO conversions under different reaction condition on Ce-γ-MnO2. (O: C2H6 + O2, S: NO + NH3 + O2, M: C2H6 + NO + NH3 + O2). Fig. 2 The profiles of (a) H2-TPR, (b) O2-TPD, (c) C2H6-TPR-MS, (d) Correlation between ethane oxidation rate at 300 °C and the atomic ratios of Ce3+/Ce4+, Mn4+/Mn3+, OS + OC/OL, and (e) XPS spectra of Ce 3d, Mn 2p and O 1s. Fig. 3 (a) Transient reaction on Ce-γ-MnO2, (b) C2H6 + (NH3)-DRIFTs, (c) The profiles of C2H6 + (NH3)-TPR-FTIR, (d) Evolution of NOx produced in C2H6 + NH3-TPR-FTIR, (e) Ethane conversions in the C2H6 + (NO) reactions, (f) The adsorption of C2H6 and NH3 on Ce-γ-MnO2 (131). Fig. 4 (a) The transient reaction in presence of ethane, (b) In situ DRIFTs of NH3 + (C2H6) adsorption, (c) In situ DRIFTs of NH3 adsorption under different treatments, (d) Integrated areas of L-NH3 at 1193 cm−1 and (e) NO oxidation evaluation in presence of C2H6 (Evaluation condition: C2H6 + NO + O2). Fig. 5 Quasi in situ XPS spectra of Ce-γ-MnO2 after treatment by different atmospheres. Fig. 6 In situ DRIFTs of (a) ethane adsorption, (b) NH3-SCR reaction, (c) simultaneous feeding of C2H6 + NH3 + NO + O2 and (d) changes in intermediates species after NH3 and NO were successively cut off. Fig. 7 Mechanism of simultaneous elimination of ethane and NOx and the interaction between ethane oxidation and NH3-SCR over Ce-γ-MnO2. Graphical abstract Ce-X-MnO2 (X = α, β, γ, δ) catalysts with four MnO2 structures were synthesized for simultaneous ethane and NOx removal. Ce-γ-MnO2 exhibited the highest performance, achieving > 80 % conversion for ethane (276 °C) and NO (120–330 °C). Various characterizations demonstrated a correlation between the activity and the abundance of Lewis acid-base pairs, with a higher amount of these species linked to better reactivity. The Mn4+-O-Ce sites were identified as active centers: ethane oxidation followed the MvK mechanism, while NH3-SCR proceeded via both L-H and E-R pathways. The inhibition of ethane oxidation by NH3-SCR reactants was primarily due to NH3 suppressing ethane adsorption and competing for oxygen species. As ethane activation accelerated above 200 °C, NO2 generated from NO oxidation tended to donate reactive oxygen, reconstructing the surface oxygen species and concurrently mitigating the NH3 inhibition. Additionally, NO2 dissociation released NO, further decreasing NO conversion at higher temperatures. Below 200 °C, new Lewis and Brønsted acid sites were generated during ethane activation, promoting NH3 adsorption and improving low-temperature SCR activity. Keywords Simultaneous elimination Ethane oxidation NH3-SCR Interplay effect Ce-MnO2 catalyst Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Nitrogen oxides (NOx) and Volatile Organic Compounds (VOCs) are widely recognized as the common precursors to the formation of PM2.5 and O3. During industrial emissions such as biomass combustion, waste incineration, and steel sintering, VOCs are often co-emitted with NOx [1,2]. NH3-SCR has proven to be the most effective and widely used technology for NOx control. Due to the impressive oxidation capabilities of SCR catalysts, there has been a growing interest in integrating VOCs removal into the same SCR system, which could offer both technological and economic benefits. Recent advances have demonstrated the feasibility of simultaneous removal of VOCs and NOx, resulting in the reduction of NOx to N2 ( 4 N H 3 + 4 N O + O 2 → 4 N 2 + 6 H 2 O ) and the oxidation of VOCs to CO2 and H2O [3]. However, existing studies have predominantly focused on aromatic VOCs, such as Chlorobenzene (CB), toluene, and benzene [4–6]. There remains a significant gap in extending this approach to the simultaneous elimination of light alkanes, particularly ethane, and NOx. China accounts for 70 % of global coke production, with VOCs from coke production contributing to 7.8–20 % of industrial emissions in the country [7]. Alkanes constitute approximately 30 % of coke oven flue gas, with ethane and propane identified as primary pollutants [8]. Ethane presents a challenge for activation due to its robust CH bond (415.3 kJ/mol), making its removal particularly difficult. The simultaneous elimination process involves complex interactions between VOCs oxidation and NH3-SCR reactions. Specifically, NOx reduction and Chlorobenzene (CB) oxidation could be achieved on MnOx-CeO2 at separated working temperature windows (100–200 °C and 200–300 °C, respectively) [9]. NOx and NH3 promoted the CB oxidation above 100 °C because the adsorption of CB was enhanced in the presence of NH3, and also NO2 facilitated the oxidation cycle. CB could promote NO conversion and N2 selectivity below 300 °C. The toluene and NOx could be simultaneously removed on MnOx-CeO2 at 150–300 °C [10]. However, SCR reactants induced deactivation for toluene oxidation due to the competitive adsorption between toluene and NO/NH3, the weak adsorption of NO2 and carbon deposit. Zhao et al. [11] supposed that NH3 preferentially react with surface reactive O species to inhibit toluene oxidation. NO could promote toluene oxidation through C 7 H 8 + 18 N O → 9 N 2 + 4 H 2 O + 7 C O 2 on CuCeAl30. These findings suggest that the interactions and underlying mechanisms between VOCs oxidation and SCR reactions are highly sensitive to the nature of the catalyst and the specific components involved. Therefore, a comprehensive investigation into the mechanisms underlying the simultaneous removal of ethane and NOx is essential to develop effective catalytic strategies. MnO2-based catalyst has been widely studied in NH3-SCR [12,13] and VOCs oxidation [14,15]. The crystal phase of MnO2 plays a crucial role in determining its redox behaviors, oxygen mobility, and surface acidity, all of which are key factors in both target reactions [16,17]. Herein, we synthesized four different crystal phases of Ce-MnO2 catalysts to explore their potential for simultaneous ethane and NOx elimination. A series of analytical techniques including O2-TPD, H2-TPR, C2H6-TPR and XPS were employed to elucidate the intrinsic properties of the different Ce-MnO2 catalysts and their correlation with catalytic efficiency. Besides, we investigated the interplay impact of NOx reduction and ethane oxidation. By combining the analysis of quasi in situ XPS and in situ DRIFTs, the mechanism of simultaneous elimination of ethane and NOx was proposed. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Catalyst preparation All Ce-X-MnO2 catalysts with different MnO2 crystal phases were synthesized by redox hydrothermal method, including Ce-α, −β, −γ, δ-MnO2. The molar ratio of Ce/Mn is 0.5. Typically, a specific quantity of precursors was dissolved in deionized water. The resulting solutions were then transferred to Teflon-lined autoclaves and maintained at designated temperatures. After cooling, the powders were washed and dried. The final samples were obtained after baking. Further details on the preparation procedure can be found in the Supporting Information. 2.2 Catalyst characterization Quasi in situ XPS: The pressed samples were pretreated in Ar at 200 °C and then heated to 300 °C. After being treated in different atmospheres for 90 min, the surface chemical composition data were collected when samples cooled to room temperature. The Ar treatment served as the blank control. In situ DRIFTs: The samples were pretreated at 200 °C for 40 min under Ar and cooled to the reaction temperature. After recording the background, spectra were collected in various reaction feed. Complete details and other characterization information, including XRD, Raman, HRTEM, XPS, H2-TPR, O2-TPD, and DFT calculations can be checked in Supporting Information. 2.3 Catalytic performance The catalytic activity evaluation was conducted in a fixed-bed quartz reactor (internal diameter 6 mm). Three main reaction types were investigated: (1) ethane oxidation (C2H6 + O2), (2) NH3-SCR reaction (NH3 + NO + O2), and (3) simultaneous removal of both pollutants (C2H6 + NH3 + NO + O2). The feed gas consisted of 500 ppm C2H6, 500 ppm NO, 500 ppm NH3, 5 vol% O2, with Ar as balance. 200 mg of sample was placed in a mixture of reaction atmosphere with a weight hourly space velocity (GHSV) of 42 000 mL∙g−1∙h−1. The evolutions of gas-phase components were monitored on line by Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectrometer (Nicolet is10). The ethane or NO conversion, CO2 yield, and N2 selectivity were calculated using the following equations: (1) X C 2 H 6 = C C 2 H 6 i n - C C 2 H 6 o u t C C 2 H 6 i n × 100 % (2) Y C O 2 = C C O 2 o u t 2 C C 2 H 6 i n × 100 % (3) X N O = C N O i n - C N O o u t C N O i n × 100 % (4) S N 2 % = 1 - 2 C N 2 O o u t C N O x i n + C N H 3 i n - C N O x o u t - C N H 3 o u t × 100 % 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Performance evaluation The catalytic performance of Ce-X-MnO2 catalysts for simultaneous elimination of ethane and NOx was evaluated, with the corresponding activity evaluation data summarized in Table 1 . Among them, Ce-γ-MnO2 exhibited the highest catalytic efficiency for both ethane and NOx removal and maintained excellent long-term stability (Fig. 1 a–c). The working temperature windows for ethane and NOx conversion over Ce-γ-MnO2 catalyst were above 276 °C and 104–330 °C, respectively. The kinetic calculations of ethane oxidation at 300 °C under simultaneous elimination condition showed that the Ce-γ-MnO2 sample exhibited the lowest apparent activation energy (86.9 ± 2.2 kJ mol−1) compared with other Ce-X-MnO2 samples (Fig. 1d). When normalized by specific surface area, the reaction rate of Ce-γ-MnO2 was found to be the highest for ethane oxidation (Fig. 1e, Table S1), consistent with its excellent ethane oxidation efficiency. The Ce-γ-MnO2 catalyst exhibited higher low-temperature activity for ethane oxidation while maintaining comparable performance in the NH3-SCR process (Tables S2 and S3). Furthermore, with the introduction of 4 % H2O, the ethane conversion dropped ∼10 % at 300 °C, while the conversion of NO remained largely unchanged (Fig. S1). Following the addition of 40 ppm SO2, there was no further decrease in the conversion of either ethane or NO (Fig. 1c). The results suggested that the ethane oxidation efficiency over Ce-γ-MnO2 was more easily suppressed by H2O and the sample demonstrated a certain level of SO2 resistance. In the presence of NO + NH3, a decline in ethane conversion and CO2 selectivity was observed, particularly prominent at temperatures below 280 °C (Fig. 1f and Fig. S2). Similar declines were also observed on other three samples (Fig. S2), indicating that the presence of NO + NH3 had an inhibitory effect on the ethane oxidation. By comparing the NO conversions in individual SCR reaction and simultaneous elimination condition, it can be observed that the introduction of ethane generally suppressed SCR activity, especially at temperatures exceeding 200 °C (Fig. 1f and Fig. S3). 3.2 The structures and morphologies The analysis of X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of the as-prepared Ce-X-MnO2 confirmed the successful synthesis of bimetallic oxides with different MnO2 crystal phases: Ce-α-MnO2 (PDF# 72–1982), Ce-β-MnO2 (PDF# 24–0735), Ce-γ-MnO2 (PDF# 14–0644) and Ce-δ-MnO2 (PDF# 80–1098) (Fig. S4a). Several diffraction peaks of CeO2 (PDF# 81–0792) were detected on Ce-α-MnO2 and Ce-β-MnO2. Raman peaks in the range of 490–700 cm−1 represented the Mn–O stretching vibrations in [MnO6] octahedra [18], further revealing that all samples possessed MnO2 structure (Fig. S4b). No distinct peak attributed to Ce–O symmetric vibration (∼453 cm−1) [19] was observed for all Ce-X-MnO2 samples, which may be due to the low amounts to be detected. Notably, the Raman peaks of Ce-γ-MnO2 obviously broadened and their intensity was much weaker, indicating Ce-γ-MnO2 had more defects. The microstructures and morphologies of Ce-X-MnO2 samples are shown in Fig. S4c. The Ce-α-MnO2 was characterized by a disordered accumulation of rods and irregular particles. The Ce-β-MnO2 consisted of densely packed irregular fragments. The Ce-δ-MnO2 featured an intertwined nanosheets structure. The Ce-γ-MnO2 showed a flower-like spherical structure composed of intersecting nanosheets. Note that some irregular pits were observed on Ce-γ-MnO2 (Fig. S4c, C3). As reported in the literatures [20,21], the surface pits were conducive to the activation and transfer of oxygen, as well as the adsorption and dissociation of reactive molecules. Combined with the benefits of nanosheet structure that can allow for easy access of reactants to the active sites [22,23], the unique structure of Ce-γ-MnO2 is also believed to contribute to its excellent catalytic efficiency. 3.3 The surface acidity The acidic properties of various crystalline Ce-X-MnO2 catalysts were identified by Py-IR. As depicted in Fig. S5, all Ce-X-MnO2 catalysts possessed both Lewis acid (L acid) and Brønsted acid (B acid) sites on their surfaces, with the intensity of L acid sites being significantly higher than that of B acid sites. According to the quantitative analysis results (Table S4), the amount of L acid sites on the surface of Ce-X-MnO2 catalysts followed the order: Ce-γ-MnO2 (77.9 μmol g−1) > Ce-β-MnO2 (58.6 μmol g−1) > Ce-α-MnO2 (46.8 μmol g−1) > Ce-δ-MnO2 (37.0 μmol g−1). Among them, the L acid amount on the surface of Ce-γ-MnO2 was 77.9 µmol g−1, notably higher than that of other catalysts. Combined with the analysis of surface oxygen species by XPS, it could be confirmed that the surface of Ce-γ-MnO2 had the most abundant Lewis acid-base pairs. As reported in the literature, the Lewis acid-base pairs on the catalyst surface can effectively promote the adsorption and activation of VOCs molecules and gaseous O2 [24]. Meanwhile, the abundant surface acid sites are essential for the adsorption and activation of NH3/NO in the NH3-SCR reaction [25]. Therefore, the higher number of acid sites on the surface of Ce-γ-MnO2 catalysts was conducive to maintaining excellent catalytic performance in simultaneous removal process. 3.4 The properties of oxygen species The reduction properties of Ce-X-MnO2 catalysts were investigated through H2-TPR analysis. As presented in Fig. 2 a, the main reduction peaks of all Ce-X-MnO2 samples were observed within the temperature range of 150–600 °C, which could be mainly attributed to the reduction of MnO2 to MnO [26,27], as well as the minor reduction of surface Ce 4+ to Ce 3+ [28]. However, the reduction behavior of O species varied among different samples, suggesting a close correlation with the crystal structure of MnO2 and the interaction between Ce and Mn species. Notably, the initial reduction temperature of Ce-γ-MnO2 was the lowest among all samples. Coupled with the maximum H2 consumption (Table S4), it indicated that Ce-γ-MnO2 showed better reducibility and contained more readily reducible oxygen species. The desorbed oxygen species of the samples can be classified into three categories based on their desorption temperature (Fig. 2b). The O species labeled as OI represented O2 (ads), O 2 2 - , O 2 - , and O - (<250 °C) that weakly bound to the surface. The surface/subsurface lattice oxygen (labeled OII) released from unsaturated metal sites at 250–600 °C, and the bulk lattice oxygen desorbed above 600 °C (labeled OIII) [29,30]. Both OI and OII are active and can be readily desorbed from the sample surface to participate in the catalytic reaction. Among all samples, Ce-γ-MnO2 presented the most active oxygen species (0.628 mmol/g, Table S4), followed by Ce-β-MnO2 (0.471 mmol/g) > Ce-α-MnO2 (0.200 mmol/g) > Ce-δ-MnO2 (0.183 mmol/g). Furthermore, the reactivity of active oxygen species was studied through C2H6-TPR-MS experiments. As illustrated in Fig. 2c, ethane could react with active O species to produce CO2 without external supply of O2, with temperatures ranking in this order: Ce-γ-MnO2 (308 °C) < Ce-β-MnO2 (341 °C) < Ce-α-MnO2 (380 °C) < Ce-δ-MnO2 (466 °C). This indicated that the Ce-γ-MnO2 contained the highest amount of reactive oxygen species and exhibited better mobility. According to the XPS fitting results (Fig. 2e and Table S5), the atomic ratios of Mn 4+ / Mn 3+ and Ce 3+ / Ce 4+ on Ce-X-MnO2 were observed to all follow this sequence: Ce-γ-MnO2 > Ce-β-MnO2 > Ce-α-MnO2 > Ce-δ-MnO2. Ce-γ-MnO2 presented the highest Mn 4+ / Mn 3+ and Ce 3+ / Ce 4+ ratios. The higher proportions of Mn 4+ and Ce 3+ on the catalyst surface may result in the charge imbalance, causing an increase in the formation of O-vacancies [31–33]. Higher density of surface oxygen vacancies can offer sufficient active sites for gas-phase O2 adsorption and activation, which is essential for the oxidation of VOCs [34,35]. O 1s spectra can be deconvoluted into three O species, including lattice O ( O L ), O species adsorbed on O vacancy ( O S ) and adsorbed H2O ( O C ) [36]. The O S + O C / O L ratio decreased in the order of Ce-γ-MnO2 (0.60) > Ce-β-MnO2 (0.50) > Ce-α-MnO2 (0.31) > Ce-δ-MnO2 (0.16), evidencing Ce-γ-MnO2 possessed more reactive O species than other samples. When analyzing the relationship between surface elemental distribution with ethane oxidation rates, a positive correlation was observed between the Mn 4+ , Ce 3+ and O S + O C ratios and catalytic activity (Fig. 2d). Meanwhile, the Py-IR results confirmed that the Ce-γ-MnO2 catalyst possessed the highest amount of Lewis acid. These Lewis acid sites could facilitate the adsorption of alkane molecules and also served as active centers for NH3 adsorption in NH3-SCR reaction [25,37]. Furthermore, the basic oxygen ions (O–, O2 – or O2 2–) on the catalyst surface can attack the electron-rich regions of alkane molecules, leading to the oxidation of alkane molecules due to their strong electrophilic properties [38]. Based on above analysis, it was speculated that the Lewis acid-base pairs on the Ce-γ-MnO2 surface played a critical role in the simultaneous removal process. In addition, the binding energy of O 1s on Ce-γ-MnO2 shifted towards lower values, suggesting better mobility of surface oxygen species [39]. 4 Reaction mechanism of simultaneous removal of ethane and NOx 4.1 Interplay Effects of ethane oxidation and SCR reaction In the simultaneous removal of ethane and NOx, the coexistence of NOx and NH3 inhibited ethane conversion (Section 3.1). Transient reaction at 300 °C (Fig. 3 a) revealed that the ethane oxidation was improved after NOx was added. However, when both NOx and NH3 were introduced, there was a reduction in ethane conversion and CO2 selectivity. Further inhibition was observed when NH3 was introduced alone. Upon removal of NH3, ethane oxidation reverted to its initial level. This demonstrated that NH3 had a significant inhibitory effect on the oxidation of ethane. According to the C2H6-DRIFTs (Fig. 3b), the band around 3000 cm−1 could be identified as the adsorption of ethane molecules [40]. The bands at 1623 cm−1 and 1250 cm−1 were attributed to deformation vibration of CH3 and bicarbonate species, respectively, both resulting from the partial oxidation of ethane [41,42]. During the co-adsorption of C2H6 + NH3, the band at 3000 cm−1 was evidently weaker compared to the independent C2H6 adsorption. At the same time, the CH3 and bicarbonates species were undetectable as well. The results indicated that the adsorption of ethane and its subsequent oxidation were impeded by NH3. Additionally, the effect of NH3 on the reaction between ethane and the oxygen species on the catalyst surface was investigated through C2H6-TPR/C2H6 + NH3-TPR experiments. As can be seen from Fig. 3c, the formation of CO2 at ∼305 °C and 601 °C corresponded to peaks of ethane consumption, suggesting that ethane could be oxidized by the lattice oxygen species on the Ce-γ-MnO2 surface. However, in the presence of NH3 (C2H6 + NH3-TPR-FTIR), the CO2 peak at 305 °C disappeared, concurrent with the formation of N2O and NO from NH3 oxidation (Fig. 3d). Moreover, the CO2 production peak at 601 °C shifted to a lower temperature of 562 °C with reduced intensity, probably due to the reaction between ethane and NO2 that produced from NH3 oxidation. DFT calculations further demonstrated that ethane preferentially adsorbed on the Ce sites with an adsorption energy of –0.20 eV, whereas NH3 exhibited stronger adsorption (–0.75 eV) on the same sites (Fig. 3f), and NO was more likely to adsorb on the O sites (Fig. S6). These findings indicated that competitive adsorption occurred between C2H6 and NH3. NH3 competed with ethane for reactive oxygen species and preferentially reacted with them, thereby significantly suppressing ethane conversion. Furthermore, the contribution of different NOx components (NO2 and N2O) to the oxidation of ethane was also evaluated (Fig. S7a). The results revealed that NO2 exhibited higher oxidation efficiency compared to O2, with its activity further enhanced at elevated temperatures (Fig. S7b). Ethane conversion was apparently higher in the presence of NO compared to independent C2H6 reaction, likely attributed to the formation of NO2 from the reaction between NO and oxygen species (inset plot of Fig. 3e). Additionally, the impact of ethane on NO conversion was also investigated. As depicted in Fig. 4 a, the introduction of ethane at 300 °C led to a notable decrease in NO conversion. In contrast, the NO conversion exhibited a slight enhancement at 150 °C. The presence of ethane did not significantly influence N2 selectivity under either reaction temperature. In the NH3-SCR reaction, the formation of adsorbed NH3/NH4 + species is the prerequisite for the subsequent reaction [25]. NH3-DRIFT experiments were conducted to investigate the impact of ethane on NH3 adsorption. In the NH3 adsorption process (Fig. S8), several peaks in the ranges of 3400–3000 cm−1 and 1700–1100 cm−1 were observed. The bands at 3352, 3235, 3145 cm−1 were related to the NH stretching of NH3 [43]. The bands at 1602 and 1225, 1189 cm−1 were assigned to asymmetric and symmetric bending vibrations of the N–H in NH3 coordinated with L-acid (L-NH3) [44]. The peaks at 1664 and 1439 cm−1 were attributed to asymmetric and symmetric bending vibrations of NH4 + adsorbed on B-acid sites (B-NH4 +) [45]. In the co-adsorption of NH3 and C2H6 (Fig. 4b), the intensity of the peaks at 1602, 1428 and 1193 cm−1 increased. Concurrently, the shoulder peaks at 1216 and 1570 cm−1, corresponding to NH3 adsorbed on L acid and B acid sites [46,47], respectively, showed an obvious increase in intensity compared to individual NH3 adsorption. These findings indicated that the presence of ethane facilitated the adsorption of NH3. Based on the XPS results of the used catalysts (Table S6), the Mn3+/Mn4+ increased from 0.17 to 0.72 after ethane oxidation, and exhibited a further increase to 1.60 after full-component reaction (M), indicating more low-coordinated Mn ions were generated on the catalyst surface. According to previous reports [48,49], the coordination of unsaturated metal sites has long been considered a typical Lewis acid site, highly sensitive to the adsorption and activation of NH3. Furthermore, as confirmed by the C2H6-DRIFTs, H could be abstracted by lattice oxygen species to generate hydroxyl groups (–OH) in the adsorption and activation of ethane, which can be acted as Brønsted acid sites to adsorb NH3. The above results suggested that ethane could facilitate NH3 adsorption and improve the SCR activity at low temperature. Furthermore, we compared the quantity of L-NH3 based on the integrated area of the peak at 1193 cm−1 (Fig. 4c). The results showed that the flow of NH3 + C2H6 resulted in the highest amount of NH3 adsorption, as evidenced by an integrated area of 1.035 (Fig. 4d), which exceeded that when only NH3 was adsorbed (0.713). When NH3 + C2H6 was introduced over NH3 pre-adsorbed Ce-γ-MnO2, it was observed that NH3 could still be adsorbed, but the adsorption amount (0.758) was lower than that of NH3 + C2H6 co-adsorption. However, after being pretreated with C2H6, the integrated area of 0.557 showed the least adsorption of NH3. This was probably due to the occupation of acidic sites by partial oxidation products of ethane, which interfered with the subsequent adsorption of NH3. Activity evaluation on Ce-γ-MnO2 was conducted to further investigate the impact of ethane on the NO oxidation. As shown in Fig. 4e, with rising reaction temperatures, the NO conversion exhibited an initial increase followed by a subsequent decrease. Upon the introduction of ethane, a significant reduction in the NO conversion was observed, particularly pronounced within the temperature range of 200–320 °C. It should be noted that within this temperature range, the NO conversion almost remained stable while ethane oxidation accelerated. Therefore, we speculated that the inhibition of NO oxidation by ethane above 200 °C was not only due to the competition between ethane and NO for oxygen species, but also because, as the ethane oxidation accelerated, the generated NO2 tended to donate O to replenish the consumed oxygen species, while simultaneously releasing NO molecules ( a d - N O 2 → O + N O ). On the other hand, the presence of ethane resulted in an increase in NO2 concentration in the NH3-SCR process below 200 °C (Fig. S9a). Combined with the NO + O2 + C2H6-DRIFTs (Fig. S9b), it was speculated that ethane inhibited the further oxidation of ad-NO2 into nitrite/nitrate species due to the competitive consumption of O species by ethane oxidation. When NO2/NOx < 50 %, the SCR activity could be improved through the “fast-SCR” reaction with higher NO2 concentration [50]. As can be seen from Fig. S9c, a condition of NO2/NOx < 50 % was observed below 200 °C, suggesting that higher NO2 concentration could improve the SCR activity. 4.2 Quasi in situ XPS To elucidate the changes in the chemical states of the catalyst surface, quasi in situ XPS analysis was conducted on Ce-γ-MnO2 following treatment under different atmospheres at 300 °C (Fig. 5 ) and the results are presented in Table 2 . After ethane treatment, the O C and O S species decreased from 21.83 % and 28.76 % to 16.78 % and 22.97 %, respectively. Meanwhile the O L / O S + O C increased from 0.98 to 1.52. It was speculated that O C and O S played a crucial role in the oxidation of ethane. After NH3 + C2H6 treatment, the O species distribution was almost consistent with that of the ethane-treated sample, confirming that NH3 consumed the same O species as ethane oxidation. However, the O species distribution was obviously different under NO + C2H6 exposure. The ratio of OC species decreased to 16.48 %, while OS and OL species increased from 28.76 % and 49.40 % to 31.60 % and 51.92 %, respectively. According to earlier reports [51], NO reacts with surface oxygen species to produce NO2, which could donate an O to restore consumed oxygen species. Therefore, we proposed that this process restructured the oxygen species on the catalyst surface. In addition, ethane treatment resulted in a decrease in Mn 4+ from 95.69 % to 89.25 %, indicating that part of Mn 4+ were reduced by ethane. Following C2H6 + NO or C2H6 + NH3 treatment, the Mn 4+ ratio declined further, particularly when NO was present (62.51 %), implying further reduction of Mn 4+ . Combined with O 1s analysis, it could be inferred that Mn 4+ and its adjacent oxygen species played a vital role in the oxidation process. Surface Ce 3+ / Ce 4+ ratios exhibited no significant variation in all samples compared to the blank. However, based on above DFT calculations (Fig. 3f), the adsorption of ethane and NH3 on the Ce sites serves as the prerequisite for ethane oxidation and NH3-SCR reaction, respectively. Therefore, we speculated that the Mn4+ OCe served as the active sites for the simultaneous removal of ethane and NOx. 4.3 In situ DRIFTs studies The evolution of intermediates during ethane oxidation on Ce-γ-MnO2 at 150 °C are depicted in Fig. 6 a. the band at 1623 cm−1 was assigned to the deformation vibration of CH3 [41]. The bands at 2980, 2931 and 2893 cm−1 were attributed to CH stretching vibrations of ethane, with the intensity increased gradually over time. As adsorption progressed, the bands at 3789 and 1420 cm−1 emerged, corresponding to the hydroxyl groups (OH) and ethyl (C2H5–), respectively [40,42], indicating the activation of ethane. Meantime, multiple bands associated with carbonate and carboxylate species were observed at 1100–1700 cm−1 due to the reaction of ethane with oxygen species on the catalyst surface. The bands at 1576 and 1457 cm−1 were assigned to acetate (CH3COO) [40,41], originated from ethyl group dehydrogenation. Other species, including alkoxide species (CH3O: 1197 cm−1), formate species (HCOO: 1602, 1558 and 1542 cm−1) and carboxylic acid (HCO: 1520 cm−1) were detected [40,52]. These oxygenates were formed through the acetate CC cleavage and subsequent oxidation. Bicarbonates (HCO3 : 1252 cm−1) [27] and carbonates (CO3 2–: 1337 cm−1) [40] were also observed and eventually transformed into CO2 and H2O. As the temperature rose to 150 °C with additional feed of O2 (Fig. S10), the intensity of bands near 3000, 1600, 1337 and 1197 cm−1 significantly decreased. Concurrently, various oxygenates (1600–1400 cm−1) became prominent and gradually decreased above 200 °C, indicating the consumed oxygen species were supplemented by gaseous O2 and the ethane conversion was accelerated. In summary, the results suggest that ethane oxidation via the Mars van Krevelen (MvK) mechanism involves oxygen-containing intermediates. Within this mechanism, ethane directly reacts with surface oxygen species. The mechanism of NH3-SCR was also studied. As shown in Fig. 6b, when the mixture of NO + NH3 + O2 was introduced simultaneously at 150 °C, the ad-NO2 (1624 cm−1), B-NH4 + (1440 cm−1), LNH3 (1602 and 1198 cm−1), monodentate nitrate (1520 and 1262 cm−1) and bidentate nitrate (1558 cm−1) [53–56] were detected. The bidentate nitrate species resulted from the further oxidation of ad-NO2, which could react with adsorbed NH3 to form NH4NO3 (1534 cm−1) [57]. By altering the introduction sequence of NO + O2 and NH3, it was confirmed that the NH3-SCR reaction on Ce-γ-MnO2 followed both L-H and E-R mechanisms (Fig. S11). After ethane pre-adsorption for 60 min, NO + NH3 + O2 were introduced simultaneously. As shown in Fig. 6c, the L-NH3 (1602 and 1198 cm−1) and B-NH4 + (1452 cm−1) were clearly detected. As time progressed, bidentate (1558 cm−1) and monodentate nitrates (1520 and 1262 cm−1), along with NH4NO3 species (1534 cm−1), increased continuously, indicating the occurrence of the SCR reaction. However, compared to Fig. 6b, the formation of intermediate species was much lower than in the independent SCR reaction. This suggested that the incomplete oxidation products of ethane cover the catalyst surface, thereby hindering the progress of the SCR reaction. When the reaction proceeded at 150 °C for 30 min in the mixture of C2H6 + NO + NH3 + O2, NH3 was cut off. As illustrated in Fig. 6d, the LNH3 (1602 and 1198 cm−1) gradually declined, suggesting their reaction with gaseous NO or adsorbed NOx species. Simultaneously, bicarbonates (1230 cm−1) and carbonates (1342 and 1337 cm−1) decreased and eventually disappeared, concomitant with an increase in CO2 (2360 cm−1). This observation suggested an accelerated conversion of these species into CO2 without NH3. Concurrently, the bands at 1631, 1600–1400, 1262, and 1243 cm−1 displayed a pronounced increase, primarily attributed to the formation of bridging, monodentate, and bidentate nitrates resulting from the SCR reaction and NO oxidation. However, the oxygenates (1600–1400 and 1252 cm−1) generated from ethane oxidation overlapped with the nitrate peaks, complicating the accurate determination of changes in the oxygenates. Following the cut-off of NO, peaks within the 1600–1243 cm-1 range decreased significantly, primarily due to the decomposition of nitrate species. The reappearance of formate (1602 cm-1) and alkoxide species (1197 cm-1) implied that NO facilitated the transformation of these intermediates. Based on the above analysis, the mechanism of simultaneous elimination of ethane and NO, as well as the interaction between ethane oxidation and the SCR reaction, is illustrated in Fig. 7 . Ce ions act as the adsorption sites, enabling the enrichment of reactants (C2H6/NH3) and establishing prerequisites for subsequent catalytic processes. The redox properties of Ce ions (Ce3+/Ce4+) could promote the exchange and regeneration of active oxygen species. Concurrently, the oxygen species surrounding Mn4+ cations is able to facilitate CH/NH bond cleavage, not only promoting the deep oxidation of ethane to CO2/H2O but also activating NH3 to form NH2 intermediates, which further reacts with gaseous NO to produce N2 and H2O. The synergistic Ce-MnO2 interplay established a continuous cycle of adsorption-activation-conversion, enabling the efficient ethane oxidation and NOx reduction. NH3 inhibits the adsorption of ethane and preferentially reacts with oxygen species, thereby significantly suppressing the further transformation of ethane oxidation intermediates (such as alkoxide and formate species). As ethane oxidation accelerates (>200 °C), NO2 generated from NO oxidation tends to release active O species, replenishing the consumed oxygen species and triggering the reconstruction of surface oxygen species. This process increases the ratio of OS and OL species, enhancing the oxidative capacity of the catalyst surface. This phenomenon not only accounts for the observed weakening of NH3 inhibition at elevated temperatures but also leads to increased NH3 oxidation, reducing the availability of NH3 for the NH3-SCR reaction. Consequently, the NO conversion decreases significantly. In contrast, at low temperature, the activation of ethane generates new Lewis and Brønsted acid sites, which promote NH3 adsorption and thus facilitate the low-temperature SCR reaction. Additionally, ethane does not alter the reaction pathway of the SCR process. 5 Conclusion Ce-X-MnO2 catalysts with four different MnO2 crystal structures were synthesized and utilized in simultaneous elimination of ethane and NOx. Among them, Ce-γ-MnO2 exhibited the highest catalytic performance, achieving over 80 % conversion for both ethane and NO at 276 °C and 120–330 °C, respectively. Besides, it showed excellent stability and maintained high activity in the presence of 4 % H2O and 40 ppm SO2. A series of characterizations were employed to investigate the surface properties and elucidate the mechanism underlying the simultaneous removal of ethane and NO, as well as their interaction. The conclusions are summarized as follows: 1. Ce-γ-MnO2 exhibited better reducibility, contained higher proportion of Mn4+ and Ce3+, and more reactive O species with better reactivity. 2. Mn4+-O-Ce acted as active sites for simultaneous removal of ethane and NO. Ethane was adsorbed on Ce ions and then oxidized to CO2 and H2O via the MvK mechanism. The NH3-SCR reaction followed both L-H and E-R mechanisms, with bidentate/bridged nitrates and ad-NO2 as key active species reacting with active NHx species through the L-H pathway. 3. The introduction of NH3-SCR reaction components resulted in the inhibition of ethane oxidation. This was primarily due to that NH3 suppressed the adsorption of ethane and competed with it for oxygen species. As ethane oxidation accelerated above 200 °C, the NO2 from NO oxidation tended to release reactive O, which in turn refilled the consumed oxygen species. This process induced the reconstruction of surface oxygen species, and concurrently mitigated the inhibitory effect of NH3 on ethane oxidation. Moreover, the dissociation of NO2 to donate O was accompanied by the release of one NO ( N O 2 → N O + O ), leading to a significant decrease in NO conversion at higher temperatures. Below 200 °C, the activation of ethane generated new Lewis and Brønsted acid sites in situ, which enhanced the adsorption of NH3 and thus favored the SCR reaction at low temperatures. coredata.dc:description: Ce-X-MnO2 (X = α, β, γ, δ) catalysts with four MnO2 structures were synthesized for simultaneous ethane and NOx removal. Ce-γ-MnO2 exhibited the highest performance, achieving > 80 % conversion for ethane (276 °C) and NO (120–330 °C). Various characterizations demonstrated a correlation between the activity and the abundance of Lewis acid-base pairs, with a higher amount of these species linked to better reactivity. The Mn4+-O-Ce sites were identified as active centers: ethane oxidation followed the MvK mechanism, while NH3-SCR proceeded via both L-H and E-R pathways. The inhibition of ethane oxidation by NH3-SCR reactants was primarily due to NH3 suppressing ethane adsorption and competing for oxygen species. As ethane activation accelerated above 200 °C, NO2 generated from NO oxidation tended to donate reactive oxygen, reconstructing the surface oxygen species and concurrently mitigating the NH3 inhibition. Additionally, NO2 dissociation released NO, further decreasing NO conversion at higher temperatures. Below 200 °C, new Lewis and Brønsted acid sites were generated during ethane activation, promoting NH3 adsorption and improving low-temperature SCR activity.
